text: He blesseth them also, so that they are multiplied greatly; and suffereth not their cattle to decrease.
text_kjv: He blesseth them also, so that they are multiplied greatly; and suffereth not their cattle to decrease.
text_niv: he blessed them, and their numbers greatly increased,and he did not let their herds diminish.
text_esv: By his blessing they multiply greatly, and he does not let their livestock diminish.
text_nlt: How he blesses them!They raise large families there,and their herds of livestock increase.
text_msg: He blessed them and they prospered greatly;their herds of cattle never decreased.
text_nasb: Also He blesses them and they multiply greatly, And He does not let their cattle decrease.
context: Psalm 107 is a psalm of thanksgiving, likely used in a communal setting after deliverance from various hardships. Understanding the historical and cultural background requires recognizing the societal importance of agricultural prosperity in ancient Israel. The phrase 'He blesseth them also, so that they are multiplied greatly; and suffereth not their cattle to decrease' reflects a predominantly agrarian society. Cattle were not merely livestock; they represented wealth, status, and the primary means of sustenance. A decrease in cattle meant economic hardship, potential starvation, and vulnerability to enemies. The multiplying of people signifies population growth and strength, vital for survival and defense against surrounding nations. Ancient Israel experienced cycles of prosperity and hardship based on their faithfulness to God's covenant. Blessing was often associated with obedience, while hardship was interpreted as divine discipline. Droughts, plagues, and enemy raids could decimate crops and livestock, leading to widespread suffering. This psalm reminds the Israelites that God is the ultimate source of blessing and provision, capable of reversing even the most dire circumstances. The imagery of multiplication is a direct echo of God's original command to be fruitful and multiply (Genesis 1:28), reflecting a restoration of divine favor and a return to the intended abundance of creation.
meaning: Psalm 107:38 carries deep theological weight. The verse underscores God's providential care and faithfulness to his covenant promises. The blessing of multiplication isn't simply about numerical increase; it represents holistic flourishing in all areas of life â€“ physical, spiritual, and societal. The fact that God 'suffereth not their cattle to decrease' emphasizes his meticulous attention to detail and his concern for the tangible needs of his people. This is not to be interpreted as a guarantee of material wealth, but rather as an assurance that God will provide for those who trust in him. The verse alludes to the concept of divine sovereignty. God is the ultimate source of blessing, and He has the power to increase or decrease according to His will and purpose. However, the context of the psalm suggests that God's blessing is often contingent upon obedience and faithfulness. The psalmist presents a picture of a reciprocal relationship between God and His people. When they cry out to Him in their distress, He hears their prayers and delivers them. In turn, they offer thanksgiving and praise for his goodness. The theological significance also touches on the theme of redemption. God's deliverance from hardship is not merely a temporary reprieve; it is a sign of his redemptive power at work in the world. He is not only able to restore what has been lost, but also to multiply it beyond measure.
application: Psalm 107:38 offers profound practical applications for modern Christians. While we may not live in an agrarian society, the principles of God's provision and blessing remain relevant. The 'multiplication' can be interpreted as growth in various aspects of our lives: spiritual maturity, relationships, skills, and opportunities to serve. It calls us to pray for growth in these areas, trusting that God can do immeasurably more than we ask or imagine (Ephesians 3:20). The phrase 'suffereth not their cattle to decrease' can be applied to our resources, talents, and even our physical and mental health. We can ask God to protect what He has given us, to prevent loss, and to sustain us in times of difficulty. This doesn't mean we will never experience hardship, but it does mean that God is with us, providing strength and comfort. The verse also challenges us to be good stewards of what God has entrusted to us. Multiplication and protection of resources are not just for our own benefit; they are for the benefit of others. We should be willing to share our blessings with those in need, recognizing that God's provision is meant to be a channel of blessing to the world. Furthermore, this verse encourages us to cultivate a heart of gratitude. When we recognize God as the source of all good things, we are more likely to use those things wisely and generously. This requires intentional reflection on God's blessings in our lives, and a willingness to give thanks for even the small things. Finally, we should be mindful of the importance of obedience and faithfulness. While God's grace is unconditional, our obedience opens us up to receive even greater blessings.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank you for your promise of provision and blessing. We acknowledge that you are the source of all good things in our lives. We ask for your blessing upon our families, our work, our finances, and our spiritual growth. Multiply our efforts for your kingdom, and protect us from loss and harm. Help us to be good stewards of all that you have given us, and to use our resources to bless others. We recognize that true prosperity comes not from material wealth, but from a relationship with you. Increase our faith, our hope, and our love. Give us hearts that are grateful for your provision and that are eager to serve you. We pray for those who are suffering from hardship, those who lack basic necessities, and those who feel lost and alone. May they experience your comfort, your healing, and your provision. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: No, Psalm 107:38 doesn't guarantee material wealth. It emphasizes God's provision and blessing, not a promise of automatic riches. It's about trusting God for our needs and experiencing holistic flourishing, including but not limited to financial security.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Does this verse guarantee material wealth to believers?

faqs.answer: This verse emphasizes God's blessing but also implies responsible stewardship. We are called to manage our resources wisely, recognizing God as the source and using them for His purposes and the benefit of others.

faqs.answer: In a modern context, 'cattle' can symbolize various forms of resources: finances, possessions, talents, or even health. It represents what we rely on for sustenance and well-being, not just literal livestock.
